Award.AwardTitle: Atomic-level structural characterization of metal/gamma-alumina interfaces combining theory and experiments
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Metal nanoparticles on gamma-alumina (a phase of aluminum oxide) are important in chemical catalysis because of their role in reducing harmful by-products of fossil fuel combustion and energy consumption during industrial chemical processes. The functionality of such material systems depends partly on the interactions between the metal with the oxide support, down to the atomic bonding at the interface. Atomic-level characterization of interfaces is challenging because interfaces are complex structures buried within the bulk. Characterization is especially difficult in a system involving gamma-alumina, which is an excellent carrier for catalytic metal nanoparticles because of its extremely high surface area, but it is also structurally fragile and thermally sensitive. Novel processing methods are combined with highly advanced electron microscopy techniques to reveal the atomic structure at the interface between this metastable phase of aluminum oxide and widely used metal catalysts such as platinum and palladium. Experimental characterization is paired with computational models that are based on the fundamental relationships describing bonding between materials to further elucidate the relationship between the structure and properties. This project provides training and research opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, and engages high school students from underrepresented groups in the exploration of science and engineering.

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Gamma-alumina is a widely used support for metal nanoparticles in industrial chemical production and catalytic converters. Although it is known that the catalyst activity is affected by metal-support interactions, the understanding of the atomic-level structure and thermodynamic properties of the metal/gamma-alumina interfaces is incomplete. The goal of this research is to examine the extent to which the local atomic structure of gamma-alumina is affected by the structure and the chemistry of the metal species at the interface. This work assesses if dense nanostructured material with a high gamma-alumina/metal interfacial area can stabilize the system enough to enable atomic-level characterization. The microstructural complexity of metal/alumina systems, the metastability of the alumina phase, and the susceptibility of alumina to damage during transmission electron microscopy (TEM) have limited atomic-level structural characterization of the interfaces in these complex systems. In this project innovative processing paths are used to create stabilized nanostructured materials that may be characterized with aberration-corrected TEM. Qualitative atomic-level structural characterization of the interfaces between the alumina and select metals (e.g., Pt, Pd) is achieved using aberration-corrected TEM. Density functional theory (DFT) is used to calculate the optimal configuration and interfacial energy of candidate structural models of the interfaces. The research objective is to use the overlap between the experimental characterization and the structural calculations to validate the interfacial structures and thermodynamic stability ranges calculated with DFT methods in these complex, metastable systems, and to connect the structural information to the thermodynamic properties of the interface, including the interfacial free energy. Graduate students involved in the project are trained in advanced TEM, data analysis techniques and in computational methods of DFT for calculating the atomic structure of the interfaces. Undergraduate students are also involved in these main research activities. Outreach activities for high school students from underrepresented groups in science and engineering introduce them to experimental methods for materials characterization and to how computational techniques are used to study atomic bonding.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Context: Metal nanoparticles on gamma-alumina (a phase of aluminum oxide) are important in chemical catalysis because of their role in reducing harmful by-products of fossil fuel combustion and energy consumption during industrial chemical processes. The gamma-alumina serves a dual purpose as a support that prevents sintering of the nanoparticles and therefore maintaining the high utilization of the expensive noble metals and as a chemically active material. The functionality of such material systems depends partly on the interactions between the metal with the oxide support, down to the atomic bonding at the interface. Atomic-level characterization of interfaces is challenging because interfaces are complex structures buried within the bulk. Characterization is especially difficult in a system involving gamma-alumina, which is an excellent carrier for catalytic metal nanoparticles because of its extremely high surface area, but it is also structurally fragile and thermally sensitive. This collaborative work using synergistic experiments and computational methods to reveal the atomic and electronic structure of interfaces in this system.

Major Accomplishment: Novel processing methods using high energy implantation and thermal processing were used to create specimens with platinum nanoparticles embedded in gamma aluminum oxide. The dense structure of the specimens and the consistent orientation of the metal nanoparticles within them enabled the characterization of their morphology and crystal orientation. Transmission electron microscopy and diffraction were used to determine the shape and crystal orientation between Pt NPs and the gamma phase of aluminum oxide. These observations were used as the basis for a detailed, fundamental density functional theory (DFT) based computational study of the interface between the nanoparticles and the aluminum oxide phase. The DFT calculations are based on the most current methods for modeling the structure and atomic bonding of crystalline materials. They yielded valuable information about the chemical bonding strength and structure at the interface. Through calculations of minimum energy configurations of electrons of individual atoms we have determine the atomistic structure of the interface and electron transfer between the different elements on the interface. This provides us with information about the binding strength and how far the effect of the interface propagates into the two different materials and gives us insight into the chemical nature of the interface allowing us to explore the effects of chemical changes on the properties of the interface.

Intellectual Merit: The chemical activity of the Pt nanoparticles depends on their size and shape and on the interactions at the interface between the metal and aluminum oxide support. This work strengthens the fundamental understanding of the system’s chemical structure and stability.

Broader impacts: This project provided training and research opportunities for one undergraduate and two graduate students, and engaged high school students from underrepresented groups in the exploration of science and engineering. The project introduced all the students to the power of combined experimental and computational approachs to scientific problems.

In July of 2017, the project team hosted four high school students from traditionally-under-represented groups in science and engineering through Oregon State University’s (OSU) Summer Experiences in Science and Engineering for Youth (SESEY) program. The SESEY program is a week-long camp held on the OSU campus that provides research and learning opportunities for the high school participants and gives the university students involved an opportunity to develop their communication and mentoring skills.

The graduate students and undergraduate researcher supported by this NSF project helped develop a collaborative experimental and computational SESEY project on the characterization of metals executed by the high school participants. The collaborative approach in the SESEY project mirrors the approach of this NSF project. The high school students hosted in the Santala and Árnadóttir groups visited each others’ host labs, compared results, and at the end of the week presented their findings in a poster session.
